sections.title: The Faith of Leap
sections.summary: This section introduces the Shapevine Missional Series, explaining its purpose to bring together various elements of missional Christianity into meaningful dialogue. It outlines the series' three distinctive areas: Living (Practical Missional Orthopraxy), Learning (Solid Missional Orthodoxy), and Leading (Tools for Missional Leadership).

sections.title: The End of the Beginning: Introduction
sections.summary: The introduction establishes the book's central theme of the 'faith of leap' through the example of Abraham's courageous response to God's call. It explores how risk, adventure, and courage are essential to authentic Christian discipleship and mission, using Tolkien's Lord of the Rings as a metaphor for the Christian journey. The authors argue that the church must rediscover its missional identity in a post-Christendom world, moving from maintenance to mission and from institution to movement.

sections.title: Series Editor's Preface
sections.summary: Alan Hirsch, as series editor, introduces the book by highlighting the surprising absence of theological exploration of adventure, risk, and liminality in Christian literature. He argues that understanding adventure is crucial for renewing Christianity and the mission of the church, as the experience of God and gospel inherently partakes of the nature of adventure.

sections.title: Chapter 1: The Spirit's Edge: Putting Adventure Back into the Venture
sections.summary: This chapter argues that adventure is intrinsic to authentic Christian discipleship and community. It explores the elements of liminality—risk, adventure, courage, and mission—and their crucial role in biblical Christianity. The authors examine how living adventurously, cultivating courage, embracing risk, and developing holy urgency are essential for the church to become the dynamic, world-transforming agency Jesus designed it to be. The chapter also discusses leadership in liminal situations and the benefits of embracing the 'edge of chaos' for innovation and growth.

sections.title: Chapter 2: Jesus Is My Disequilibrium: Where Friends Become Comrades
sections.summary: This chapter introduces the concept of communitas—the deep sense of comradeship that forms when people engage in shared liminal experiences. Drawing from Victor Turner's anthropological work and examples from skydiving, war, and biblical narratives, the authors demonstrate how liminality creates communitas. They explore how the church was meant to experience this form of togetherness through mission, arguing that true Christian community emerges not from safety but from shared adventure and risk. The chapter provides practical guidance for embedding adventure spirituality into church culture.

sections.title: Chapter 3: A Walk on the Wilder Side: Overcoming Fear in Pursuit of Wild Hope
sections.summary: This chapter addresses the role of fear in Christian life and the need to overcome risk aversion. It explores how faith itself is fundamentally an act of courage and risk, examining the relationship between fear and discipleship. The authors discuss how excessive fear leads to vices like cowardice and apathy, while the fear of the Lord provides proper perspective. They examine the educational aspects of adventure, principles of expeditionary learning, and how to develop pioneering spirits that can overcome fear and embrace the wild hope of the gospel.

sections.title: Chapter 4: The Hero's Journey
sections.summary: This chapter explores the universal pattern of the hero's journey as articulated by Joseph Campbell and applied to Christian discipleship. Using examples from Paul's missionary journeys, Celtic missionaries, and contemporary film, the authors demonstrate how the gospel story itself follows the hero's journey pattern. They argue that when mission organizes discipleship, believers become heroes in their own stories, embarking on adventures that require mentors, allies, trials, and transformation. The chapter also examines the missional matrix framework for understanding how discipleship, mobilization, societal engagement, and communitas work together.

sections.title: Chapter 5: Getting Over Risk Aversion: Extracting Truth from Dare
sections.summary: This chapter examines the nature of risk and how churches can overcome risk aversion. It explores the history of risk assessment, prospect theory, and loss aversion, showing how Jesus addressed these issues directly. The authors discuss how contemporary society's obsession with removing risk has created a 'risk society' that actually inhibits authentic living. They examine leadership principles for risk-averse organizations, arguing that churches must learn to 'surf the edge of chaos' and embrace adaptive leadership that disturbs rather than directs, designs rather than engineers, and discovers rather than dictates.

sections.title: Chapter 6: Missional Catalysis: Thinking Differently about the Church and Her Mission
sections.summary: This chapter argues that mission should be the catalytic function that organizes the church's other essential functions: worship, community, and discipleship. The authors trace the 'great divorce' between mission and church that occurred when mission was outsourced to specialized societies. They examine the four marks of the church and make a theological, historical, and practical case for why mission must catalyze the other functions rather than worship. The chapter demonstrates how mission-shaped churches experience enhanced worship, deeper community, and more effective discipleship when mission organizes their life together.

sections.title: Chapter 7: The Risk of Neighborliness: An Invitation to Take the Plunge
sections.summary: This chapter explores how missional communities must take their local context seriously, becoming good neighbors in the places where God sends them. The authors examine the problem of 'suburban homelessness' where church leaders don't belong to their neighborhoods. They present Paul Hiebert's framework for critical contextualization, showing how churches can engage their culture without compromising the gospel. Through examples from Cambodia, Texas, and the UK, the chapter demonstrates how embracing neighborliness—saying yes to invitations, listening to local rhythms, and putting down deep roots—creates authentic missional engagement that transforms communities.

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.summary: The conclusion summarizes the book's central argument that adventure is not incidental but essential to authentic Christianity. The authors affirm that God is a God of adventure, and therefore the church must be a place of great adventure and risk. They argue that Christianity is an adventure of the spirit or it is not Christianity, calling readers to repent of obsession with safety and security. The chapter ends with Jack London's creedal affirmation about living fully rather than merely existing.

sections.title: Notes
sections.summary: This section provides comprehensive endnotes and citations for all chapters of the book, including references to biblical texts, theological works, sociological studies, and other sources cited throughout. It serves as a scholarly reference guide for readers who want to explore the ideas presented in greater depth.
